title: Using C# dynamic Keyword To Replace Data Transfer Objects
summary: For this post I'm going to show 3 examples of using the C# dynamic keyword when deserializing input data instead of using data transfer objects. Many modern applications need to accept data from a variety of sources. Often times we create data transfer objects just to handle requests and responses to and from the data source. Using dynamic in C# reduces the need for data transfer objects and keeps the logic that depends on the 3rd party data source contained to one place.
author: Carl Layton
